TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate representing the Prime Minister. In answer to a number of questions last Thursday, you described Senator Short's failure to comply with the Prime Minister's code of conduct `as a side issue'. You refused to acknowledge there was any conflict of interest involved and you said that you `did not regret anything in relation to this matter'. Minister, having now had some time to reflect on this issue, do you accept that this is in fact a very serious matter, that both Senator Short and Senator Gibson clearly breached the Prime Minister's guidelines and that the opposition and the Australian people are entitled to regard such breaches as unacceptable?

—I referred to `a side issue' because I must say that I was more concerned with issues of unemployment, debt and disadvantage—the big issues that are facing Australia at the moment, and the issues that we inherited and are seeking to do something about. Yes, ministerial standards are important. I might say in passing that Senator Short is an honourable and decent person who inadvertently breached the guidelines. Furthermore, when he discovered that he had given a ministerial approval that might be seen to be in conflict with that, he offered his resignation to the Prime Minister. That was accepted and he has resigned. He has therefore paid a very high price for the ministerial standards that have been set by the Prime Minister. That really ends the matter.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you recall that you were invited twice last Thursday to put your views on this affair on the record in this Senate chamber and that you said, `No, I do not regret anything in relation to this matter' and later you said, `Therefore, in no way do I regret his behaviour in relation to this matter.' Minister, have you changed your mind?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I said and I reiterate—

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It is a touch boring. I said that there was no deliberate breach by Senator Short. I am confident that that was the case. I am confident that it was inadvertent. I guess that is why I used the word—a `technical' breach. There is no suggestion that he sought to personally gain from any decision he made. He has acted in an honourable and proper way and he has paid a very high penalty.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment. Last week you informed the Senate, Minister, of the establishment of an inquiry to examine solutions to Australia's growing urban air pollution problem. The community is not only increasingly concerned about air pollution; it is also concerned about other emissions into our environment. The public rightly believes that it has a right to know what substances are being emitted into the environment. Can you inform the Senate of what steps the government intends to take to ensure the public has access to information about pollutants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I can inform the Senate that the federal government has today taken a major step towards the establishment of a national pollutant inventory. Senator Patterson is correct to say that this is an issue of extreme importance to the public. Since assuming this responsibility for the environment portfolio, my office has had as much correspondence on the issue of air pollution and the solutions to air pollution as on any other environmental issue.

ANSWER.PARA: The national pollutant inventory will be an important step in guaranteeing the public's right to know what substances are being emitted into the environment. The inventory will provide publicly available annual summaries of hazardous chemicals released into the environment from nominated sources. The data is supplied by those who release substances into the air, land or water, including industry and other relevant government authorities.

I can inform the Senate that cabinet today has given the green light to a draft proposal for a national pollutant inventory, which will form the basis of negotiation with the states and territories under the National Environment Protection Council. When the council met for the first time in Perth earlier this year, we were able to gain the support of the states and territories for the NPI to be pursued by the Commonwealth as a measure under the NEPC proposal.

Although the previous government invested some $6 million of taxpayers' money into the development of an NPI, it was not even able to get up a first meeting of the NEPC let alone progress it further. We will now be able to take to the next meeting of the NEPC, which is to be held in late November in Brisbane, a draft of a measure which we hope will then be endorsed by the NEPC. It will come back for final approval and, hopefully, within the not too distant future will be put in place and therefore the Australian public will have the right to know the legislative basis which is the equivalent of that which has already been provided in many other developed countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Hill. Are you aware that on 17 May the Prime Minister assured the House of Representatives that the guidelines that were laid down in A Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility would be complied with in full? Is it not true that in the five months since that assurance was given the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has been exposed as being in breach of the guidelines, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has been exposed as being in breach of the guidelines and, most recently, the former Assistant Treasurer and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer have been similarly exposed? Is the Prime Minister unable or just plain unwilling to enforce these guidelines?

—It is true that the guidelines set a very high standard and we do not apologise for that. We believe that the Australian people are entitled to that. The Prime Minister has said that ministers are expected to keep those guidelines. As a result of the breach that just occurred of those guidelines, even though there is no suggestion there was any intention of personal benefit that would flow from that breach, a minister has paid a very high price—the highest price a minister could pay. I would have thought that that is the proof that this government intends to maintain high standards of ministerial conduct. Perhaps, as one of my colleagues said, you ought to look at your own book, at your own record before you come in here criticising others.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not true that the Prime Minister's document entitled A Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility has been completely devalued and completely exposed as nothing more than posturing on the part of the Prime Minister? I ask you: were the Prime Minister's guidelines simply a device to win popular support and have they now been jettisoned along with so many other of your government's pre‐election commitments?

—That is just a load of nonsense. A minister has lost his job. I do not know how this senator can come in here and talk about posturing. This is not posturing. This is a demonstration of the very high—
—It took the opposition and media to expose it.
—Senator Short's banking shares have been on the record for years.
—It was exposed by Labor.

—There was no exposure by the ALP. Were they on the public record or not? They were on the public record. Because of this conflict of interest, from which he gained nothing personally and no-one has suggested that he sought to, he has nevertheless paid the very high price of resigning. Therefore, there is no issue; there can be no debate but that this government intends to maintain and uphold these very high standards that it has set for itself. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. In a weekend news article the minister is quoted as supporting the retention of Australia Post in public ownership, which I support. In that article you were quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government is not obsessed with the privatisation of public enterprises.
You further went on:
In each case, the individual circumstances and market environment need to be considered to determine what ownership structure best serves the public interest.
Can you advise the Senate whether these are accurate statements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that was an accurate report and a statement that needed to be made in terms of the approach that governments should take to privatisation. Australia Post has made very substantial productivity gains and provided enhanced services to its customers since it was corporatised in 1989. If one looks at the statistics since that time, one finds that profits are up from $45 million to $344 million, dividends to government are up to $143 million, employee numbers are down about 3½ thousand, industrial action is from 7,150 days to 70 days and labour productivity is up 32 per cent against a national gain of 13.4 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It ought to be clear that Australia Post is performing very well by any standard. Labor, in government, said back in 1993 that there is no reason why you should not continue to review and assess the performance of government business enterprises and see whether they can do better. In a press release on 15 November, Mr Beddall said that the government would be monitoring changes closely and would conduct a further review in 1996-97, which was consistent with his government's view that a public monopoly must justify the continuation of its monopoly position.

Some 55 per cent of Australia Post's revenue still comes from reserve services. It is therefore appropriate that there should be a review by the National Competition Council to consider the remaining limits on competition in the postal services market. The reason for that is that it is simply in the best interests of consumers to see whether Australia Post could do even better or others might be able to do even better by delivering better quality services and lower priced postal services.

That is why it is very disappointing to find that, against the background of Labor taking the high moral ground on this issue in government, in opposition they have simply reverted to type. Mr Crean had the temerity to suggest that that general approach was one which the opposition was prepared to support if continued services to rural and remote areas were guaranteed—a respectable position to take—but it is completely at odds with the neanderthal approach taken by Senator Schacht on this issue. He simply dashed off a press release saying that the opposition has declared that it was not interested in supporting any changes to the present operating rules and regulations of Australia Post.

How much more head in the sand can you get? If that is not blind opposition, I do not know what is. You have not been prepared to look at the outcome of a review before you say no. If that is not simply ideological nonsense at its highest, I do not know what is. I would have thought that, at the very least, the opposition now would be trying to stake out some policy alternatives, to get some policy coherence back into the debate, not simply to be negative. What we have here is negativism raised to an art form. It is very disappointing that that seems to be the attitude.

I can understand why Senator Kernot was reported a week or so back as saying that it is hard for Labor to sound credible on the partial sale of Telstra when you sold the Commonwealth Bank. You remember, of course, that Mr Beazley was the one who, at one stage, was asked in caucus how Labor would explain to the masses that they were opposed to the privatisation of Telstra when they had privatised everything else. Mr Beazley told Bob Brown, `Don't worry, son, just get out there and tell them the opposition's going to privatise Australia Post as well.' That is about the depth to which they have sunk. In the Sydney Morning Herald last Saturday, Mr Beazley was asked about opposing the sale:
Would a Beazley government oppose further privatisation? `There isn't anything left to privatise,' Mr Beazley chuckled wryly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Your time has expired.
—That says it all—no policy commitment, just hypocrisy.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should sit down when I call `Order!' at the end of the time allowed for your answer.

—I address my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Minister, you would be aware that today is Australia's Breast Cancer Day. Would you please inform the Senate of what actions the government is taking to raise awareness of breast cancer, to increase the effectiveness of early detection and to improve research into treatment of the 7,000 women who are diagnosed with breast cancer each year?

—This, in a very real sense, is a life and death question and, for Australian women, it is a most important issue which has had more attention in the last few years than it has had in the many years before—and rightly so because we have been losing about 2,500 women a year in Australia to breast cancer. There is no need for many of those deaths if early detection is encouraged. The issue is that currently one in 14 women in Australia will be detected as having breast cancer but early detection gives the greatest chance of survival. The good news is that Australia is at last starting to make some inroads into the statistics both by early detection and treatment and medical research and also by the simple community awareness of what breast cancer is, what the risk factors are and what we women can do to minimise the danger to us.

BREAK.PARA: The day is a call to action for women from the ages of about 35 up to 70, but it also aims to motivate the wider community. Those men who love the women in their lives need to share the responsibility of making sure that they do self-examine, that they do have regular check ups and that, if they are in the 40-plus and certainly in the 50-plus age groups, they do avail themselves of the two-yearly mammography screening which is provided by the federal government.

The theme for this year is `Take care, take action'. It is largely organised by the Australian Cancer Society in association with Breast Screen Australia and the National Breast Cancer Centre, and it has the government's full support. The key messages for the day are: if you have any breast problems, see your doctor as soon as possible; if you are over 50, have a screening mammogram every two years through Breast Screen Australia; and if you are over 35 or have a family history of breast cancer, do regular self-examination.

I am wearing a pink ribbon today, which I draw to the Senate's attention. This is the fund raiser part of the day. The funds that are raised will go to the Kathleen Cunningham Foundation for Breast Cancer Research, which was established in 1994. This government has provided it with direct funding of $1 million in this budget, with up to an extra $1 million for dollar for dollar matching of private donations.

There is a national phone-in from six till nine this evening with health professionals available to answer questions about breast cancer. I do urge those who may be listening to the broadcast of the Senate to avail themselves of that opportunity.

In the five years to 30 June this year, Breast Screen Australia performed over 1.67 million screening tests—527,000 in the last financial year. Early detection gives the chance of doing something about this menace. I urge Australian women and those who love them to take note today, do something to help breast cancer research and do something to save the women in your life.

If you work together with us, if we put that $1 billion in place, we earn income on that $1 billion, and we add to that our normal recurrent expenditure, we could provide an annual appropriation over the next five years of very substantial sums of money that could make a real difference to vegetation, to streams and waterways, to the national reserve system, to coasts and seas, and that would be something very worthwhile for you to do. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, what is the difference between a tax and a surcharge?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say there is one thing you can say about the Labor Party's questions committee: they are absolutely predictable. Senator Sherry, I think about 24 hours ago I said, `Senator Sherry is going to ask me what the difference is between a tax and a surcharge. He is very interested in this issue.' So here we go, Senator Sherry: a tax can be defined as a compulsory unrequited payment demanded by government for its support. A surcharge can be defined as an additional charge. It can be a charge on an existing tax which is applied in a particular circumstance.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much. After all these months, you are the first economic minister who can tell us what a tax and a surcharge are. —Senator Sherry, they also said that after I had answered that question you would have a supplementary question. I have some absolutely top advisers. The surcharge can be defined as an additional charge. It can be a charge on an existing tax which is applied in a particular circumstance. So there we are, Senator Sherry. I refer you to one and I can assure you that—

—A tax is defined as a compulsory unrequited payment demanded by government for its support. So it is all explained there, Senator Sherry, and thank you for the question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Following his recent visit to Japan and Korea, could the minister describe the outlook for supply of Australian resources—particularly coal, liquid natural gas and uranium—to these countries and to elsewhere in Asia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is significant that we have to rely on coalition questions on matters of great importance to Australia. My recent visit to Korea followed very hard on the heels of the APEC minister's meeting in Sydney. The forecasts at the APEC minister's meeting were that economic growth in APEC would be substantially higher than in the OECD countries. In fact it is envisaged that the APEC region will be the focus of global growth over the next 10 or 15 years. Hand in glove with economic growth is a forecast of some $2 trillion required for energy infrastructure within APEC. This will present enormous opportunities and challenges for APEC and Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: In Korea and Japan I met with government ministers, power utilities, gas companies, steel mills, major trading companies and Australian business interests. What came out of those meetings was great news for Australia. There are enormous opportunities, not just in the supply of energy materials but for more value adding in Australia and the sale of technologies and equipment into the region.

In view of the projected growth and thus demand in the region, the major concern of all those people was security of supply. While reliability of supply was raised, it was security of supply which was predominant. What was said to me on a number of occasions was that long-term relationships should be given preference to newcomers; in fact, the term used was `Latecomers should be treated as newcomers'.

BREAK.PARA: I expressed the view that, while Australian companies valued the long‐term relationship, it was up to them to decide on capital investments and markets and the role of government was to facilitate the process. What this means for Australian companies has been a major change. Whereas, in the past, Australian companies with the support of the then government sought foreign equity to participate in Australian companies to secure markets, we now have foreign companies seeking equity to ensure security of supply.

From an energy perspective, the countries continue to diversify their energy feed stocks so that there are roughly equal demands for gas, coal and uranium. They also tend to diversify between countries and within countries, and this is simply a reflection of the fact that they have very few indigenous supplies of energy materials. The projected energy demands from these substantially increased demands for LNG, steaming coal, uranium and coking coal will mean opportunities for expansions and new mines which will be of great benefit in regard to direct and indirect employment and thus the creation of real jobs.

All parties expressed support for the coalition's policies, specifically in industrial relations, attacking the budget deficit and making the Native Title Act more workable, as the implementation of those policies will mean a more competitive Australia and security and reliability of supply. The coalition is committed to develop a strong, strategic vision for sustainable development of our energy resources for the next 25 years, and this will be outlined in the green and white papers.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McGauran for that question. The government will be consulting with interested parties regarding appropriate regulatory frameworks for the regulation of privacy issues in the non‐government sector. A detailed discussion paper has been released, outlining the issues involved in an extension of the privacy protection in to the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is aware that there is some support for the extension of the privacy principles to the non‐government sector, and I understand that the Democrats are supporters of that. I know that because the support for the privacy principles being applied to the non‐government sector is indicated on their Internet home page.

For the benefit of senators not familiar with the privacy principles, one of them in particular states that where personal information is collected for the individual concerned that person should be aware of the purpose for which the information is being collected. So while I was looking at the Democrat home page I was particularly interested to see the way in which it invites Internet users or surfers to become involved in a number of topical, political issues, including: gun control, ABC funding, higher education funding and Austudy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you read it yourself?

—Yes, I did. In the case of guns and the ABC, Internet surfers are invited to print off a petition and gather signatures. I am pleased that you are interested in this, Senator Kernot, because other people will be interested in what you have to say about it. Alternatively, the Internet users can enter their personal details into the form provided on the screen and click on a `submit entry' button. They are told: `Your submission will be added to the growing list'. This clearly implies that a person will have their name added to a petition or a list of protesters being compiled somewhere. As all senators know, petitions require a signature, so the best the Democrats could possibly be offering is that they will pass the protests on.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as these petitions, people accessing the site are invited to `Send a postcard to the Prime Minister' on the issue of ABC funding. Because the postcard asks that, the Internet user is clearly given the impression that the postcard will be sent electronically to the Prime Minister. Similarly to the case of the petitions, the sender is asked to enter their personal details onto the postcard form and again click on the `submit entry' button. The technological awareness the Democrats are trying to portray through their home page slips up somewhat however when you realise that the Prime Minister does not have an Internet address.

Similarly, on the issue of higher education funding and Austudy, people are invited to enter their personal details into a form and press a `submit entry' button and, by implication, send an electronic message to me. I do have an e-mail address but in the past two months I have not received a single electronic message of the form being used on the Democrat home page. If the Prime Minister cannot receive electronic mail and I am not getting the mail, one of two things is happening: either I am the only person looking at the Democrat home page or they are pretending to people using the Internet that they will send their protests on. They are not sending them on either electronically or in hard copy to either the Prime Minister or me, and that does invite the question of whether the Internet is being misused to collect issue based address lists, which would of course be a breach of the privacy principles which the Democrats so strongly support being applied to the non‐government sector.

—Ministers but—
—And parliamentary secretaries? Have they been poring over them?
—You have been reading them, haven't you?
—They have been reading them too.
—Order!
—It says:

ANSWER.PARA: Ministers (this and subsequent references to ministers should be read including parliamentary secretaries)
Ministers—
read in those terms—
are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in an area of their portfolio responsibilities.

He explained in some detail that he does not make policy decisions. Therefore there had been no conflict of interest and therefore he was not obliged to divest himself of shares. Nevertheless, following the matters raised against Senator Jim Short and in order to ensure that there can be no misrepresentation to the community, my wife and I have decided to take this action today.

For the record, these shares were purchased jointly several years ago, before I entered Parliament. They resulted from a superannuation payout made by a former employer. These shares and others were invested for the long term and specifically for the purposes of retirement income. I am not a short term share trader.
I would have thought that that more than adequately explains the course of action undertaken by the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it true, Senator Hill, that ministers and parliamentary secretaries are required to divest themselves of shares only when they have been caught out by the Labor opposition? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Ministers then apply the rules to their record of shareholding, as is already on the public record. They do that in accordance with the rules set down by the Prime Minister. They are very demanding standards—there is no doubt about that. We accept high standards for this government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

It is quite unnecessary, it is dishonest and of course it has been a Labor Party wide exercise.

ANSWER.PARA: This time, however, it is Senator Neal who has been caught. Senator Tierney has quoted from that letter, in which they expressed their disappointment at Senator Neal. They said:
The information in that report was misleading and caused undue concern to our aged community.

Senator Neal, are you listening very carefully? Your report was misleading. It `caused undue concern to our aged community' and they deserve an apology from you. The company secretary went on to discuss the benefits of our reforms in her letter to Senator Neal. She said:
Residents will continue to get the care they expect, this will not change. Any extra charges will be means tested and only those who are able to pay more than the base fee will be required to do so.
She said:

Financially disadvantaged will still be cared for, in fact aged care facilities will get greater subsidy from the government for those residents. Not for profit organisations such as Woy Woy Community Nursing Home will continue to take people who need our care as the major criteria for entry.
She also said in her letter:
. . . you—
Senator Neal—

failed to advise your readers that this entry contribution is in a form similar to an interest free loan and is refunded when a person leaves the facility. I hope you are going to give up your scare campaign, although—

—Yes; why doesn't she stand as a candidate. Perhaps that is what she is on about, Senator Patterson. But let us focus on the greatest need, which is to make sure that the elderly in our community are cared for and are not frightened in this disgraceful way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister representing the Prime Minister (Senator Hill), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to senators' interests and the Prime Minister's Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility.

The simple situation that we face, now that Senator Short has gone, is that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Gibson, should go too. The circumstances in relation to Senator Gibson are no different from those that surrounded Senator Short. Senator Short was in breach of the ministerial guidelines of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. Senator Gibson is also clearly in breach of Mr Howard's ministerial guidelines. Mr Howard has said that a minister or a parliamentary secretary must divest themselves of their shareholding in their relevant area of responsibility. Mr Howard says that it is not optional. Mr Howard's guide to ministerial responsibility says that it is not optional. It is a requirement for every minister and every parliamentary secretary.

Senator Gibson is responsible for Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission. The 26 March press release of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) indicates that Senator Gibson has responsibility for `design of laws in relation to cheques and bills of exchange'—a responsibility that is clearly and squarely in the banking sector. He had responsibilities for overseeing the new arrangements for cheque clearing house procedures allowing superannuation companies to provide cheque arrangements for customers. This is an open and shut case of a parliamentary secretary who does have a conflict of interest. I say again: Senator Gibson must go.

Until today Senator Gibson had a very significant portfolio of shares in the National Australia Bank and in the Bank of Melbourne. He also, apparently, retained shares in Amcor, in Woolworths, in CRA, in AGL, in BHP, in BTR, in Boral, in Brambles, in CSR, in FH Faulding, in National Foods and in Simsmetal. Last Thursday it was Senator Gibson who came into this chamber and said, `I am not involved in banking.' They are Senator Gibson's own words—`I am not involved in banking.' He said, `I can assure the Senate that I have had no conflict of interest during the last six months, nor do I expect one to occur.'

Of course, it took until Sunday before he announced he would sell his banking shares—Sunday, after Senator Short reluctantly, finally was dragged kicking and screaming out of the ministry. It took until Sunday before Senator Gibson announced he would sell his banking shares.

BREAK.PARA: Of course, he should have been sacked along with Senator Short on Wednesday or Thursday of last week by the Prime Minister. But Senator Gibson is a parliamentary secretary in a government that is led by John Howard, and that is the crucial thing. These are Mr Howard's standards of ministerial responsibility. Senator Gibson represents Mr Howard's standards of parliamentary propriety. Of course, they are very, very low standards.

We have seen from Mr Howard weak and vacillating leadership on this issue, weak and vacillating leadership from a Prime Minister who is either unable or unwilling to ensure that his own code of conduct is acted upon by ministers and parliamentary secretaries in his own government.

Senator Hill, in this chamber, is an even weaker link in a chain of weak leadership in this government. Last Thursday Senator Hill came into this chamber and said, `I do not regret anything in relation to this matter.' He said in this chamber, `In no way do I regret his'—Senator Short's—`behaviour in relation to this matter.' We have a situation where, because of pressure from the opposition, John Howard did regret it publicly in the House of Representatives but failed to sack his minister. He did not even raise the matter of resignation with Senator Short. That is how weak and vacillating this Prime Minister is. Senator Short sacked himself. Mr Howard is weak and gutless and has been exposed as just that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Hill.
—Don't tell me you're finally going to the barricades.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It was best described as forced theatre, I would have said, Mr Deputy President, listening to Senator Faulkner trying to drag something further out of this rather unfortunate story. I am quite prepared to say, as I said in question time, that I still regard Senator Short as an honourable and decent person. He made an inadvertent error. As a result of that, he has paid a very major price in parliamentary life. That, if anything, demonstrates not only the high standard that is expected of this government—
—Try to say that with a straight face.

—a high standard not only in what is done but what is perceived to be done. But it also shows that ministers who fail to meet those tests will have to pay a very significant price. So I should have thought today would have been the day that the opposition would have come into this chamber and congratulated Senator Short on being prepared to stand by such very high standards and to resign in those circumstances. Because, as I said, there has been no suggestion, not even by this lot on the other side, that in any way was Senator Short seeking to benefit himself—no suggestion of that at all—through shares that had been held for years, shares that were held well before he became a minister, shares that were on the public record. There has been no secret at all in this. Senator Faulkner came in and wanted to claim credit for achieving the exposure of these shares. Senator Faulkner failed to recognise and acknowledge that the fact that Senator Short held the shares was on the public record. Anyway, there had been an inadvertent breach of the standards and that price has been paid.

SPEECH.PARA: Not being satisfied with that, this opposition now decides that the next element of sport is to have a go at Senator Gibson, another honourable and decent senator. I sense a touch of envy in some of these criticisms. I, like most on the other side, am not a shareholder. Nevertheless, I do not envy those who have accumulated a reasonable shareholding through hard work and diligence. Furthermore, they are entitled under these guidelines to hold their shares provided that there is no conflict of interest.

As I said in question time, `Ministers are required to divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities.' Senator Faulkner is really saying that Senator Gibson, because his tasks are so generic, should be obliged to sell all of his shares.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he should be sacked by the Prime Minister. Do you understand that?

—Labor is saying that somebody in Senator Gibson's position should not hold shares at all. But that is not what the guidelines say. The guidelines say—using my expression—that if a conflict of interest arises from the holding of shares, then they should be divested.

BREAK.PARA: Our position is that, under the rules, Senator Gibson need not have sold these shares at all. Nevertheless, as a precautionary approach and for the reasons that he put in his press release, which set it out very well, he has decided to do so. I congratulate him again on demonstrating not only high standards in this instance but going beyond those demanded by the ministerial guidelines. So, again, I should have thought that Labor would have come into the chamber today and applauded what Senator Gibson has done rather than condemn him for doing that.

The reasons for the sale of the shares have been set out in the press release. Certainly, the fact that he held the shares was on the public record. The areas of his responsibility, which I described as generic, are on the public record.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the point.
—What you do, Senator, is test the facts against the rules. In those circumstances, there was no reason why he had to sell them at all. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill totally misses the point in this debate. He missed the point three or four days ago when he referred to these breaches of the ministerial guidelines as `technicalities' and as a `side issue'. We have seen how much of a technicality and a side issue it has been since Senator Short announced his resignation yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to the press release of the Treasurer (Mr Costello) of March this year when he outlined the responsibilities of the previous Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short) and the duties of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Gibson). I hope Senator Gibson will participate in this debate today to indicate to us why he will sell his shares and what he will do with the proceeds.

It was very clear that Senator Short had responsibility for administrative matters relating to the banking laws and a range of matters on insurance and superannuation. What did Senator Short hold? Thousands of shares in the ANZ bank—it was very clear. Senator Hill is right, it was on the record. As an opposition, when we were checking the record, we were rather amazed that Senator Short continued to hold shares in a banking stock and, at the same time, have responsibility for the development of administrative matters in the banking sector and insurance and superannuation.

When we checked this record, we looked at Senator Gibson. Let us look at Senator Gibson's responsibilities—point 2 under this press release, `Design of laws in relation to cheques and bills of exchange'—and then at Senator Gibson's share portfolio. The portfolio is quite extensive. The important area there is the case of NAB, 5,000 shares, and the case of the Bank of Melbourne, 2,300 shares. He has some direct responsibilities relating to banking and a very important and controversial issue, the issue of the clearing house for cheques, and he holds bank shares.

There is a direct conflict of interest. Let us look at this document A Guide on Key Elements of Ministerial Responsibility of the Prime Minister, Mr Howard—not a Labor document, a document laid down by your government when you were elected to government, promising integrity. This is your document, your promise, which the Prime Minister is failing to uphold.

Specifically, I challenge Parliamentary Secretary Gibson to participate in this debate. He has the opportunity here now to get up and tell the Senate why he is not in conflict with these guidelines, why he has maintained this share ownership for the last six months.

I hope he gets up and outlines that, because Senator Gibson's holding in NAB—as I informed the Senate during question time—has moved from $58,150 to $67,650. TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rest of the shares. Go through the whole lot.

—In the Bank of Melbourne—$16,675 to $19,320, or $2,645. Now that is a total profit of $12,145 in just six months. `A nice little earner' as Arthur Daley would say, Senator Gibson. What about the battlers out in Lindsay? They would love this nice little earner—$12,145 in just six months.

SPEECH.PARA: This highlights the connection between this government, their two chief economic ministers, the former Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, and Senator Gibson, and their connection with the banks in direct contravention of these ministerial guidelines. It also highlights the nice little profit, donated to charity in Senator Short's case. I hope in Senator Gibson's case it will be donated to charity as well. They have been sitting on a nice little profit for the last six months. The parliamentary secretary and the former Assistant Treasurer were the only two senators who sat in this place in direct contravention—if you check the shareholdings—of the ministerial guidelines laid by down by Mr Howard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics really is getting to a new low every question time, isn't it? We think the Labor opposition have hit the bottom of the barrel, yet somehow they manage to go a little bit further each day. If the Australian Labor Party genuinely want the Australian people to believe that these guidelines are the measure that they are now adopting, you have to ask the question: `Why didn't they adopt those guidelines whilst they were the government?'
—We did.
—Senator Collins says, `We did.'
—It is called the Cabinet Handbook , Senator.

—I am sure everybody up in the gallery will recall Carmen Lawrence, the member for Fremantle, who was found to have lied under oath and was allowed to keep her ministerial commission. `There is no sin in lying under oath; you can keep your ministerial commission'! It is not a problem according to the Labor Party, not a problem for those on the opposite side. I can understand the gross discomfort that they are feeling and the need to interject and howl as they are doing, because they know that they enter this debate with a degree of duplicity not seen in this parliament for a long, long time.

SPEECH.PARA: We move on to Ros Kelly, the former member for Canberra. What a dynamo she was in the Labor ministry, caught out in a big way using taxpayers' money to try to bolster marginal seats, and allowed to continue and continue within the ministry of the Australian Labor Party.

—But Carmen Lawrence was found to have lied.

—She lied under oath.
—Order! There is much too much interjection on this south‐west corner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, we have from Senator Abetz an avoidance of the issue, an attack on personality, a raising of irrelevance and everything to dodge the issue. The issue here is that at the election the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) declared that he would introduce a new standard of parliamentary honesty in Australia. He set down a standard for which ministers had to comply. The issue in this parliament is the credibility of the Prime Minister and the adherence to those standards proclaimed by him by his own ministers, junior ministers and parliamentary secretaries.

SPEECH.PARA: The record is of non-compliance. The record is that the Prime Minister on this subject must regard it not as a core undertaking to the Australian people but rather as an undertaking he feels obliged on whim and on wish to break. Therefore, his conduct is to be characterised properly as being weak in leadership and sneaky in behaviour. One can blame his ministers less than him if they then adopt the same approach to how they might comply with the guidelines he has laid down. They can be blamed less than the Prime Minister but they can be not excused at all from not complying with the guidelines that have been laid down. The fundamental responsibility rests where the buck stops, and the buck stops with the Prime Minister.

What has been said in this debate that is true is that not only did the Prime Minister set down these standards but when they were broken he did not act to enforce them. It required Senator Short to do that. While Senator Short's reputation may have risen because he did resign of his own volition, as we understand, the Prime Minister's reputation for honesty and integrity in public life declined. It was Senator Short who made that decision, not the Prime Minister.

The issue also relates to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator Gibson, who holds a range of shares including shares in several banks. When Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and with specific responsibilities for the Corporations Law of Australia, for the Australian Securities Commission, for the design of laws regarding cheques and bills of exchange and for a range of things which relate to banking, he held shares in banks. He held shares in significant banks—the National Australia Bank and the Bank of Melbourne—while discharging his parliamentary responsibilities and his executive responsibilities as a parliamentary secretary.

The defence to that is that, if a decision came his way that related to his shareholding, he would pass it back to the Treasurer (Mr Costello). I think a public interest issue here is: is that what is meant by the Prime Minister's guidelines, or is that a confection in order to avoid the implication of not being in the range of apparently not being complicit and therefore having to resign?

Let us go to no lesser authority in order to understand the meaning of the guidelines than the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister himself said that the guidelines refer to ministers—and in that reading we include parliamentary secretaries—where it is in `relevant areas of responsibility.' What were the relevant areas of responsibility for parliamentary secretary? They were, as I have said, issues of the design of law for banks and bills of exchange and other matters related to the banking industry. They included the Corporations Law and the Australian Securities Commission.

There is no question that that falls within a relevant area of responsibility, and I think on second thought Senator Gibson may have recognised that because he then moved to divest himself of those shares. This raises the question that, given that we are all of the same view, why does he not now stand down from his position as parliamentary secretary as Senator Short has stood down from his position as minister? If he does not stand down, why does the Prime Minister not act?

If leadership is vacillating, indecisive and unsure of itself, the people who follow that leadership will act accordingly. The buck stops with the Prime Minister. There is a clear issue here: the Prime Minister should act.

There is a huge question of conflict of interest between when a person wears a party hat—in this case a Liberal Party trustee who is also on two major Liberal Party fundraising organisations—and when he is at the same time the Chairman of the ANZ Bank. We have to start thinking about opportunities when it might be okay when the Liberal Party is in opposition because it thinks that these people will not have any influence on policy, but when the Liberal Party moves from opposition to government and you are the chair of a major bank and you have these links with the party, then quite clearly your party hat and your corporate hat overlap. TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Ellison, I present the second report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, relating to treaties tabled on 10 and 11 September 1996, together with the transcript of hearings and minutes of proceedings. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
This Report deals with the group of six treaties which were tabled on 10 and 11 September in both Houses.
Without exception, the Committee supports the proposed treaty action in each instance. This is largely a reflection of the non‐controversial nature of the treaty obligations under review.
There are, however, four points I think that should be made in connection with this report.
Firstly, we have proposed some simple procedures for tabling future amendments of the International Convention on Whaling.

Unless a contracting state lodges an objection, amendments to this Convention automatically come into force 90 days following the date of notification from the Secretariat of the International Whaling Commission. If this situation arises, the amendments do not come into effect for any of the Contracting Governments for an additional 90 days.

The practical effect of such a default procedure in this instance is to preclude compliance with the Government's new procedures for parliamentary scrutiny of treaties, which prescribe that treaty actions should be tabled in Parliament for at least 15 sitting days.
On this occasion, the proposed amendments were presented to the President of the Senate on 19 August and tabled in the House of Representatives on 10 September 1996.
The Committee appreciates the Environment Minister's intention to bring these amendments before the Parliament.
We consider that the following procedures would be appropriate, should this situation recur:

The Minister should write to the Committee providing details of the proposed amendments, together with a copy of the National Interest Analysis within 10 working days from the date of notification by the Secretariat of the IWC.
This material should then be tabled at the first opportunity in both Houses when Parliament sits, along with a brief explanatory note, or reference in the NIA, outlining the unusual arrangements.

The Committee considers that adopting these procedures would allow timely consideration of future amendments to the Convention or Schedule, as well as ensuring the primacy of the proceedings of both Houses.

Secondly, NIAs tabled so far have generally included reference to the provisions for denunciation of or withdrawal from treaties. While it has not made a formal recommendation on either matter, the Committee believes that it would be assisted in its work if NIAs also included reference to provisions for attaching reservations to treaties.

The third point I would like to make is that in this report and in its First Report, the Committee has met its remit from the Parliament of 15 sitting days to consider all 31 treaties tabled to date. This has been possible only as the result of the unexceptional nature of most of these treaties, and the commitment of Committee members to meet a heavy work load in a new area of Parliamentary inquiry which satisfies public need and community involvement.

As I pointed out in tabling our first report, this is the newest and second largest committee in the Parliament. While our first two reports have dealt with treaties which have not generated large public responses, the same cannot be said about the other two inquiries we are holding.
The response to the inquiry into the Subsidiary Agreement with Japan on long line tuna fishing has been significant and generated a heavy round of hearings.

In the case of the inquiry into the UN Convention to combat desertification our first public hearing has revealed that there are a number of complex issues to be resolved, including the implications of the High Court's Teoh decision on the application of the convention.
Tomorrow a large group of treaties will be tabled with a number of substantial matters for us to examine.

This raises the issue of the 15 sitting day period available for parliamentary scrutiny. The Committee is not unhappy about the limitations imposed by this period. I think, however, that all of its members would want me to point out that there will be times when the 15 sitting day limit cannot be observed.

Given the amended Sitting Pattern for the rest of 1996, it will probably not be possible for us to report on all of the group to be tabled tomorrow on 21 November. That is when the 15 days elapses for this group of treaties.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs is already aware it is likely that some of this group of treaties will not be reported on within this time frame.
Some of these treaties could even become the subject of longer inquiries.
My final point is this. At this early stage of the Committee's life, it is becoming clear that our work is the subject of considerable public interest, which is to be expected.
We are a new committee which only came into existence at the start of this Parliament as a result of public concerns about the treaty‐making process.

This is a lively committee with a considerable and varied workload. I would like to pay tribute to its members for their hard work. The new members of the Parliament have been particularly dedicated in their attendance, and I hope this will continue.
I commend the report to the Senate.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

I want to proceed with this motion despite the confusion about the process that we had on Thursday last. What we wanted to do at that time—and we agreed that this should happen today—was to move to the substantive issue which is under debate. The substantive issue is to do with the responsibilities of the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill, whether or not he was able to fulfil his responsibilities under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act and whether or not he has been compromised in terms of those responsibilities.

I refer to an article in the Townsville Bulletin which quoted the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) as having said that he got personally involved in the decision. Also, the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, told a National Party conference that the government would give conditional support to the development. Both of those statements were made on dates well before Senator Hill had made his determination about the possible adverse effects on world heritage values of the area.

Further information has come to light that either the Prime Minister or the Deputy Prime Minister may have indicated these commitments in writing. This is serious and has serious implications under the World Heritage Properties Act as it may indicate interference or influence with regard to the environment minister's responsibility under this act. As you can appreciate, Mr Acting Deputy President, if this were the case, it would be an extremely serious matter and open to legal challenge.

I note that Senator Hill has not denied that such correspondence exists, so I presume that he is accepting the proposition that such letters have been written. He has complained about the trouble we have caused him in having to produce documents. I might point out that in this regard I agreed to three extensions to the time on the original return to order. He only complied with the order at midnight on the day on which he himself had nominated, namely, Tuesday 18 October 1996, and he tabled the documents during the adjournment debate.

Hinchinbrook has been a long running saga of government ineptitude. In reply to Senator Hill's reference to FOI, I have spent some hundreds of dollars paying to obtain other documents, particularly from the Queensland government, under FOI legislation. That is how seriously I take this particular issue. Step after step in the long trail of permits to this day have revealed that there has been maladministration, shortcuts and grave abuse of policy and process. According to a number of pieces of correspondence I have, there have been attempts, particularly by the developer, Mr Williams, to beat government officials into submission. I have no reason to believe that the latest round of approvals is any different.

I indicate to the Senate that last week, when I questioned Senator Hill, he did not give me an answer, particularly about whether or not he was subjected to threats or pressure from Mr Williams. He simply referred to the basis in terms of his statement of reasons on which I based that question.

Let me point out that the developer's energies so far have been directed at removing mangroves and wanting to create an artificial beach and to dredge the Hinchinbrook Channel. This is in spite of the fact that, for the whole of the period under dispute, the developer has had permission, permits and access to the site itself, and nobody could have stopped him from developing that site. There was no problem with it. Yet he has not poured one cubic metre of concrete. All he has sought to do at every point is to impact on world heritage values, to destroy the environment and to attack those who stand in his way.

The developer's actions will impact on world heritage values such as seagrass beds, fish nurseries and dugong populations. Also, the resort would mean a significant increase in the number of tourists visiting adjacent areas of the Great Barrier Reef and Hinchinbrook Island. That increase—this is on the record in many places—would adversely affect these fragile environments.

The reason I am putting this on the record is to show that the minister has serious responsibilities under the World Heritage Properties Act. If these responsibilities have been interfered with in any way—even if it is by the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister—that is a very serious matter indeed and one which this Senate has a deep interest in. It underlines the reason for asking for these documents, so that we can know one way or the other.

It is not too late to prevent the damage which is being done in this area. It is still possible to negotiate a much more appropriate development in line with ecotourism guidelines. But to be able to do that, we need to stop this developer from proceeding with the kind of development which he has projected, to make him understand that if he were only reasonable, other reasonable people could negotiate with him a much better development for the environment and also for the town.

But the developer, Mr Williams, has a long history of using bullying and threats to get what he wants. The Senate Privileges Committee declared that he had threatened me, although it said that he would not be sued for contempt because it did not stop me from carrying out my duties as a senator. This afternoon I have been told by another member of this Senate that he too was threatened some years ago by staff of Mr Williams. In spite of those threats, I am willing to continue to try to get an appropriate development for the site for the sake of employment opportunities for the small township of Cardwell which is nearby.

I cannot stress enough to the Senate how important it is to obtain this correspondence from the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister to add to the picture of how the consents were given by the federal government. SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations and the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1996 Nos 206 and 207, respectively, and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

If I could condense and clarify that, I simply move that the Senate disallow the government's export woodchip regulations which were gazetted a couple of weeks ago and which put into place a sham as far as any real move towards the protection of Australia's fast disappearing native forests, their ecosystems and the vast array of wildlife within them, including many species facing extinction.

Around the world we see the rate of extinctions now of our fellow creatures at about 50 per day. Dr Norman Myers, the great British scientist who was one of the signatories to the appeal to the world by some 1,200 scientists in 1992 to turn around the factors leading to mass extinctions and which may ultimately lead to the unsustainability of life on the planet, including that of we human beings, was here two weeks ago. He pointed out that it is the loss of forests, above all, which is creating the onward rush to extinction around the world.

We as a northern, developed, rich country ought to be taking a lead in a world stand against the destruction of what is going on in the Amazon, Siberia, Papua New Guinea and elsewhere. But instead, we are going in the wrong direction. Along comes the Howard government which touted itself before the election as the best alternative and as a government which was going to protect the interests of the environment. In the months since it came to power, it has greatly accelerated the rate of destruction of Australia's native forest heritage. Whereas when this government took office, it was already at the obscenely high level of 5¼ million tonnes of Australia's native forest being exported as woodchips to the paper mills and then to the rubbish dumps of the northern hemisphere, the regulations which the minister has now brought in will allow that rate to go to 6¼ million tonnes per annum for starters—a nearly 20 per cent increase.

But on top of that, the government has lifted the lid off the destruction of forests on private land where very many of the most precious environments exist in this country, where many of those endangered plants and species of animal life are hanging on. That will be accelerated without limit. Except this limit: the regulations say that the minister has a responsibility to appoint an inspector—there is no qualification on what that person's expertise should be—to ensure that the forests are degraded. When you look at the definition of degraded, you find that it does not exist. It can be anything. Worse, under these regulations, the government will be able to blame parliament, or at least give parliament the responsibility as minister after minister allows what he or she judges as degraded forests to go to the woodchippers.

Looking at the regulations, they provide no incentive for forests to be protected if they are of high conservation value. In fact, as these regulations read, it is very clearly possible for a landowner who does have very important forest with very important species within it to allow that forest to be degraded, to allow it to be cut down and then to apply for an export woodchip licence so that when the inspector arrives, he or she finds it has been degraded and says, `Tick, it can go to the export woodchip mill.' It is the wrong way to go.

We ought to be giving incentives to those private landowners who are protecting what is part of the nation's heritage. We ought to be regulating to penalise to the extent that it prevents the destruction of that heritage where private landowners do not have the wider interests at heart or, indeed, need an incentive through government to protect that part of the national heritage which they own.

The regulations also allow for trial shipments to be sent to new markets. No limit is put on those. They also allow for unlimited export woodchipping to come from areas classed as having undergone a forest agreement. Just in the last couple of days we have seen the potential for such an agreement in East Gippsland. Once implemented, it would mean unlimited woodchipping within the parameters of that agreement from East Gippsland. But that agreement, which this minister and his state compatriots would like to enter into, protects not one tree in East Gippsland in national park—not one piece of protection which has teeth in it. And wild and wondrous parts of East Gippsland, including parts which are the stronghold of endangered species like Leadbeater's possum, the sooty owl and the longfooted potoroo will not get national park protection under this process. But the woodchippers get the protection; they get the sky's the limit nod through these regulations from the federal government.

It is much better that the Senate disallow these regulations and require the minister at least to work by the 1986 regulations, which would then come back into force. There is one remitting reason for that. The minister himself—whether it be the minister for forests, the minister for primary industries, or the minister for the environment—would be required to own up to the responsibility for what they are doing when they sign the export woodchip licences which allow mega‐companies, like Boral, Wesfarmers in Western Australia and North in Tasmania, to maraud national estate forests, to log World Heritage value forests, as in the Tarkine, Picton and Huon valleys in Tasmania and in the Great Western Tiers.

They cut from under them the living universe in the forests for so many of Australia's marvellous marsupial and bird species, and a myriad of insect species, many of which are still not identified or known to science and many of whose roles are still not even understood. Successive governments give the nod to the bulldozers and the chainsaws moving in on this fantastic natural asset which is being destroyed at a record rate in this wonderful country of ours. Each morning we wake up to find there is less forest than ever before in history.

I want to point to the criticality of this vote. This vote is another means of accelerating the obscene export woodchipping industry which is marauding our forests. I do not believe it is ethically correct that people who hold shares in these woodchip companies ought to be voting for this motion which is in their benefit, which will add to their profit lines, which will give them licences for the increased destruction of our forests and export—at the profit of those companies—to the paper mills of the Northern Hemisphere.

The increasing export under this government, outside the woodchip trade, is of whole logs from Tasmania. This government is currently giving a licence to the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, now named Forestry Tasmania, to export 100,000 tonnes of plantation softwood logs, totally unprocessed—with them go the jobs—to the Northern Hemisphere. The mechanism that was contained in the previous regulations provided a very important means of ensuring that state and territory governments did progress the national forest policy statement. I will come to his defence and say that Senator Hill's omission from this process illustrates the lack of balance the Howard government has on forest policy and on environment matters more broadly. I am afraid it does nothing other than demonstrate the complete lack of influence that poor old Senator Hill, as the environment minister, has in this particular government.

The minister must commission a report on the forest by an experienced and trained person who is independent of the applicant. The person could be an expert in weeds or plant pathology and write a report which completely misses the major aspects of forest biodiversity and potential regeneration. There are no safeguards in these regulations for important conservation values even being identified, let alone considered.

There is also no guarantee that forests which provide important habitats for native fauna will be protected. That is a subject that Senator Brown touched on in his contribution earlier. It is my view that the regulations limit the classification criteria for degraded forests to the floristic composition of the forests. There is no acknowledgment in the regulations that a forest, which could be judged degraded from a floristic point of view, might be an important habitat for native fauna.

The government's approval of unlimited woodchipping on privately owned land has significant biodiversity implications which the government is ignoring. The conversion of such forests to plantation instead of regrowth forests is a major step backwards for biodiversity. Plantations are seen normally as additional to existing native forests, reducing pressure on them in forestry production, not physically replacing them.

The clearing of native forests in the 1960s, the 1970s and more recently to permit the establishment of pine plantations has resulted in the destruction of substantial areas of native forests in Australia. That is a matter of fact that even someone like Senator Hill probably would not deny. From the point of view of biodiversity, there is comparatively little difference between a eucalypt plantation and a pine plantation when compared with native forest, be it degraded, regrowth or old growth.

The government's forest policy is very clearly at odds with its vegetation policy. Poor old Senator Hill says he is keen to throw millions of dollars at revegetating this country through the national vegetation initiative. However, Mr Anderson's woodchip regulations actually exacerbate the problem by encouraging the clearing of forest on private land. The government is sending out contradictory signals. I think poor old Senator Hill's real vegetation policy has been exposed.

There is no doubt that these regulations represent a major setback to the protection of the environment. They include no incentive for the industry to invest in downstream processing, and they represent a significant broken promise by the Prime Minister.

The Howard government has broken its promise to the Australian people—its solemn promise that it would protect the environment. It is now asking this parliament, this chamber, to endorse that betrayal. For the opposition's part—the Labor Party's part—we will not join the government in that betrayal. We do not want any part of this process and we will support the disallowance motion.

The new system would allow the export of an additional one million tonnes of woodchips sourced solely from sawmill residue and silvicultural thinnings. In many instances, this wasteful material would have been burnt rather than utilised to improve Australia's trade deficit in timber products. I remind the Senate that in current dollars the 1993‐94 trade deficit was $1.8 billion—and continues to worsen.

Another category of licence has been introduced to encourage the establishment of native hardwood plantations on private land. Woodchip exports will be permitted from the clearing of privately owned degraded forest where the forest is not needed for the comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. Assessment of the degraded nature of the forest will be by a qualified, independent assessor.

Much of Senator Brown's criticism of the regulations is based on the misconception that the granting of an export licence somehow gives the licence holder a right to harvest material. This, of course, is not the case. The responsibility for land use management, including the management of forests, lies directly with state governments. The licensees will also continue to be required to comply with all Commonwealth, state and local environment protection laws.

Given the states' role as forest managers, the most appropriate way to ensure forest values, including environmental and production values, are protected is under agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. The government therefore remains committed to the national forest policy statement and its central goals of creating a world class forest reserve system and providing long‐term security for native forest based industries in the context of ecologically sustainable forest management and use.

These goals will be achieved through regional forest agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. Large areas of forest which might be needed to establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system are now protected under the deferred forest agreements and interim forest agreements with the states. Industry is restricted to harvesting in areas outside these areas of interim protection. The DFAs and IFAs identify areas which might be required for the CAR reserve system and the states have agreed not to harvest in those areas for either export or domestic use.

This agreement not to harvest these possible future reserve areas is a significant achievement and will result in greater conservation gains than a ban on the export of woodchips after the trees have been harvested. RFAs will be negotiated to ensure that a CAR reserve system is established and that harvesting outside those reserves is done in an ecologically sustainable manner.

The commitment of this government to the sustainable management of forest resource is also demonstrated by the provision of an additional $48 million for accelerating the RFA process. Comprehensive regional assessments leading to RFAs will be accelerated without compromising the integrity of the process to achieve a lasting resolution to the forest policy impasse of the past decade.

However, the government must keep the pressure on to ensure RFAs are completed as quickly as possible. Therefore, as I have said, exports from areas not covered by RFAs will be prohibited from the year 2000. This important and necessary condition to achieving a world class forest reserve system is entrenched in the regulations which are now the subject of this motion to disallow.

As I said, Senator Brown fails to understand the consequence that, in the event of the success of his resolution, there will be no ceiling in the regulations that will take effect. But neither in the regulations that will take effect nor in the previous regulations is there a requirement to prohibit woodchip exports from the year 2000 for areas not covered by the regional forest agreements.

While the government can use the old unprocessed wood regulations, it will be required to implement the transitional woodchipping licensing arrangements by policy rather than regulation. There are obvious benefits in implementing such controls through regulation, not the least of which is the encouragement to the states to stay on course with implementing regional forest agreements.

I ask: does Senator Brown realise the effects this motion would have on regional Australia and industry investment? This government recognises that medium- to long-term security is a critical issue for industry. Previous decisions created a great deal of uncertainty for forest based industries and communities that depend on such industries.

Many billions of dollars, principally for value adding projects in fibre board, wood pulp and paper production, would be invested by the forest industries if they were certain about long-term government policy direction and resource supply. This would enable more woodchips to be utilised domestically, increasing employment and providing value added products for export markets.

Another point which I believe Senator Brown misconstrues is that these woodchips would come from trees that would be utilised for other purposes. Because there is greater value in producing saw logs and timber for furniture purposes, obviously that would be the chosen destination for timber that would be suitable.

This timber is, however, entirely suitable for the production of printing grade papers. At the moment, the export market offers the highest returns for this valuable resource. Domestic processors' requirements for pulp are fully met from local suppliers. They cannot use all of the woodchip produced in Australia. Much of this material would have, in the past, been burnt rather than earning valuable income for all Australians.

PARA.BREAK: The government believes that its forest policy has been made on firm and balanced decision making consistent with its recogni tion of regard for all Australians who want our forests for both their outstanding natural and cultural qualities as well as a source of continuing employment and wealth. The new regulations are a key part of the government's commitment to Australia's economic, social and environmental needs. I, therefore, urge honourable senators to vote against the motion before us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some amazement that I listened to what the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) said, particularly in the last five minutes. SPEECH.PARA: For a possum to climb up some of the trees that I have seen remaining is quite a feat. Anything like a powerful owl actually roosting or landing in them is really something that I think defies the imagination. When you take into account the damage that is caused by strong winds in these areas, within about six months of this logging occurring even the few spindly trees that are left for these purposes are no longer standing.

I also suspect that the minister has not walked through these forests a year or two later. What we see coming back is not this ecologically sustainable forest that he has been talking about, with biodiversity and all the rest of it. Thanks to the chipping and management practices of the larger companies in particular and their regime of cutting not only in the coupes but also in adjacent coupes—certainly, I have walked in areas of East Gippsland that they should not have touched—you have only seed trees of a couple of species left.

BREAK.PARA: The temperatures of the burning regime are such that you basically eliminate many of the other species, the undergrowth species, that would have come back.
