They are so slow growing that one of the greatest incentives for these companies is to get out and plant their own plantations because they flourish far better than what remains of our native forests several years after logging.

To just look at where this chamber is today, it is with some disgust that I come in here yet again to debate this issue. What the government is asking us to do is to make a choice that boils down to which is the least worst decision. As has already been said, we have before us yet another broken promise.

For the minister to suggest that the environment movement, that the conservation groups, are in any way supportive of his action also suggests that, as well as not spending very much time looking at the issue on the ground, he certainly has not spent a lot of time talking to those conservation groups that we have been talking to—the major conservation groups that have any interest in forests. After deliberation, after looking at the situation, I cannot find one that has got back to us to say that they are supporting what this government is doing, that they are supporting the new regulations.

That is why the Democrat position eventually has been quite easy to make. We will be voting against this government's new regulations thanks to what the conservation groups have said to us about the open-endedness of these new regulations. For the minister to suggest that there is a problem going back to the old regulations because there is no ceiling, I would point out to him that there is no ceiling under the new regulations.

This government, like the previous government, has totally missed the point. The logging industry in our native forests is not sustainable. We are clearing and chipping at a record rate but, fortunately, we also have plantations coming on stream. Fortunately, despite the disincentives that this government is putting in the way, the plantation industry is beginning to thrive. Certainly Mount Gambier in my home state of South Australia has been thriving for quite some time in that area. But the native industry is not only going to run out of timber—you only have to look at the job losses, particularly in the areas I know in southern New South Wales and East Gippsland. The industry also is costing the taxpayer a huge amount of money, and it has long run out of any community support.

If we look at where these regulations are leading us, we see that there is very little support for what this government is continuing to do—that is, wholesale clearing of what little remains of our native forests. If you talk to people in many of the towns in rural areas that actually rely on native forests for their livelihoods, you will see bigger and bigger question marks appearing as they—particularly those in East Gippsland—realise that so many jobs have already gone because we are simply running out of timber. As tourism picks up in many of these areas they realise the long-term damage being done to their future, where their future really lies.

If you talk, as I have been doing recently, to those people in the plantation industry, those who are actually out there investing money, which is what the minister has just said he wants—this is where the real investment should be going—they are also disappointed at what this government is doing. You are encouraging a non‐sustainable, dying industry. By doing that you are actively discouraging the plantation industry and, to some extent, even farm forestry. Farmers are saying to us, `They are giving away native forests. What is the point of me dedicating some of my farmland to forest? I turn to look specifically at the disallowance motion. It certainly is a case of the devil and the deep blue sea. On the one hand, with the 1986 regulations, as has been pointed out, we go back to an unlimited level of culling and to the usual ongoing brawl over licences. But at least that will all be out in public. At least we will be able to take part in it and we will actually be able to see what this government is doing. The 1996 regulations would also mean unlimited logging, unlimited licences, but by a much more circuitous route.

There are no limits on woodchip licence tonnages set out in the 1986 regulations, but for all intents and purposes the so-called ceiling in the 1996 regulations is meaningless because of the loopholes. There are loopholes in the transitional licence tonnages, which already include an increase of one million tonnes in so-called `residual' woodchips—in other words, every possible habitat tree has gone now. And there are also loopholes in the unlimited licence tonnages available under the degraded forest licences.

What do we mean by `degraded forest'? According to the new regulations, in relation to each forest to which the application applies, it is reliant on the general state of the forest and, in particular, whether the floristic composition of the forest has been altered significantly by reason of disease, weed infestation, harvesting and other human activities. In other words, if the farmers let the stock in and that stock takes out the understorey, they have probably taken out the vast majority of species, because there are only a few species that grow into tall mature trees in most districts and the bulk of the species are actually in the understorey.

So I cannot imagine that we will have much problem at all for those who wish to chip what remains of their native woodlands. Just the very definition here in these regulations opens it up to wholesale action. It will be open slather. Where is this government's commitment to greenhouse? It talks about needing a carbon sink, it talks about planting a billion trees. Yet here we have the means by which we can effectively cut trees at 10 times the rate at which all the Landcare groups across this country are trying to plant trees.

We have a huge problem in two states in particular. In Queensland we are looking at a greater amount of cutting. We saw 600,000 hectares go last year in Queensland. We already have applications to clear‐fell over a million hectares. On top of the clear‐felling that is going on in many of our farming areas, if we include our woodlands and forests, we will see what real commitment this government has to the environment. It really is a sham.

Also, the definition of degraded land in the regulations is such that you could very easily drive a truck, or certainly thousands of chainsaws, through it. In Queensland I have had representations which estimate that 40 to 50 per cent of the forests which are being lined up for logging in that state are now on private land. Figures in Tasmania seem to be not quite as horrific, but Senator Brown could probably give you some figures on the amount of private forest that could be chipped under these new regulations. This really begins to show us how insidious these regulations are. If you add that to the existing level of woodchipping, to the existing level of clear‐felling—certainly in Queensland—you will see what horrific possibilities we have out there.

I want to focus quickly on one clause, clause No. 8. This allows for not one but four different types of licences—transitional, degraded forests, RFAs, and restricted shipment. In each case there is a clause about the application of the licence and then a clause about the consideration of the application for the licence.

Let us look at the real comparison between the 1986 and the 1996 transitional licences. In the application for transitional licence the applicant must specify the region from which a specified tonnage of hardwood woodchips will be derived and the tonnage of any woodchips derived from sawmill residues and silvicultural thinnings referred to as residue woodchips in the regulations.

PARA.BREAK: The 1996 regulations have a clause which states that, before deciding whether to grant a transitional licence, the minister may consider 12 matters. As well as the matters referred to in the 1986 regulations these include: the need to protect areas that are or may be required for the national reserve system; the desirability of encouraging invest ment in value added production forest and related industries; the possible economic and social effects of the decision to grant or refuse the application; the possible effects on the operations of the applicant of the decision to grant or refuse a licence and the applicant's record of adherence to export licence conditions.

BREAK.PARA: Surely, it is very strange that there is no requirement to consider these matters. After listening to Senator Hill I think this shows how transparent this government's arguments are. If there were any real commitment, there would be a requirement that all of these issues be taken into consideration before the decision on the application was made. This is one of the many major loopholes in the regulations, and I remind the government of what happened in December 1994 with Minister Beddall.

This clause must be amended. Obviously, if these regulations get through in this place, it cannot be, but if they are refused and the minister comes back with a much improved set, one of the improvements will be that there is a requirement to do all of those things. The way these regulations are written it appears that processing in Australia of woodchips derived from native forests will not be a priority and, in fact, may be positively discouraged. It is clear from the economic analysis of Australian Pulp and Paper Manufacturers that new pulp will be established only—and I repeat the word `only' for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson)—in close proximity to substantial plantations. Native forests, it seems, for this industry, are going to have no major role in the future even if they are still required to supply some currently existing mills.

I close by reiterating that the decision today will be a bad one for our precious native forests, whichever way the vote goes. It will mean that many million tonnes of our native forests will continue to be taken and that all of us, as taxpayers, will be continuing to subsidise an unsustainable industry. If this minister really wants investment, if he really wants to tackle our trade deficit in this area, he should be doing everything possible to encourage the plantation industry and putting some barriers to the wholesale exploitation of our native forests.

The Democrats will vote to disallow these new regulations. If the government takes these regulations away—after they are, I hope, defeated—I would recommend that, before bringing back any regulations to put in their place, they talk to economists and the plantation sector, and that they go back to the drawing board and bring some revised regulations that have also involved some genuine consultation with the environment movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brown's approach to the issue of regulations governing the export of hardwood chips derived from native forests has hardly been surprising, given his ideological opposition to the commercial use of native forests—and, I might say, to just about any commercial operation that anyone wanted to start up.

SPEECH.PARA: This approach is confirmed in the Native Forest Protection Bill 1996 introduced by Senator Brown on behalf of the Democrats, which aims to eliminate native forest logging and woodchip exports in favour of plantation. Fortunately, the bill will never see the light of day in the House of Representatives although Labor, as it continues to goosestep away from the national forest policy statement, may yet support it in the Senate.

That the Australian Labor Party supports the motion of disallowance is ample evidence that its rhetoric about jobs is totally and utterly hollow. The regulations provide certainty for a key part of the native forest logging industry, and the importance of this should not be underestimated after the damage caused by the illogical and commercially inept approach adopted by Labor. I could not help but note in the closing remarks of Senator Lees that she said that it did not matter which way the vote went, it was going to be bad; and then she said she would support the disallowance. Really bizarre stuff, I have to tell you.

These regulations plot a sensible, practical transitional approach to dealing with woodchip exports as we negotiate with the states to put in place regional agreements over the next three years. For the past week, Senator Brown has been running the line that the government is attempting to push through new unlimited woodchip export licences. First of all he was saying when the previous regulations were disallowed that there would be unlimited licences; now he is objecting to the regulations that are before us.

He has supported his arguments with statements that he has issued in recent weeks implying that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) was on the verge of approving export licences of 10 million tonnes of woodchips. This is patently untrue. Senator, you are loose with the truth. Senator Brown has not let the facts get in the way of a good, emotive scare campaign. In fact, he reminds me of ratbags years ago who used to wander around outside theatres saying. `Repent. The end is nigh.' They used to be brave enough to put a time and date on it, and when the time came and went and the end of the world did not happen they were bitterly disappointed.

Now Senator Brown seeks to disallow regulations which impose a ceiling on woodchip exports for native forest regions which are not covered by regional forest agreements. The Canberra Times of 10 September reports Senator Brown as saying that he would vote to disallow the regulations so that the government would have to take responsibility for each decision on logging rather than have it ratified by the parliament. The Commonwealth makes no decision on logging. Senator Brown should be aware that unsuccessful applicants for export licences have the right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that unsuccessful applicants may appeal such decisions to the tribunal which, if these regulations are disallowed, will not be constrained by any export ceiling. Much of Senator Brown's criticism of woodchip exports is based on the misconception that the granting of an export licence somehow gives the licence holder a right to harvest the material.

This is simply not the case, as the responsibility for land use management, including the management of forests, lies directly with the state governments. We must move away from this incorrect perception, fostered by the previous government, that export licences offer protection for the environmental and heritage values of our forests. They do not. The licences confer on exporters the right to export pulpwood; they do not confer the right to harvest. Harvesting may occur in any place and the wood may be processed within Australia.

There are no Commonwealth controls on the domestic use of this material, nor are there controls on the export of processed wood such as sawn timber and paper. The Resource Assessment Commission stated in its 1992 report:

. . . the question of woodchip exports should be considered separately from forest management practices. If the main point of concern is that logging practices associated with the production of woodchips from native forests are unacceptable on ecological or other grounds, it would be more effective to control those practices directly or to implement a different system of land use, rather than impose export sanctions or intervene in established commercial activities.
In the report Adding Further Value to Australia's Forest Products of September 1993, the Industry Commission states:

Some perceive the export controls as a means of pursuing environmental objectives. However, environmental objectives are more efficiently addressed by measures which impinge on all logging operations (eg. codes of logging practice), not just logging operations associated with the production of logs and woodchips destined for export markets.

Given the states' role as forest managers, the most appropriate way to ensure forest values, including environmental and production values, are protected is under agreements between the Commonwealth and the states. The government, therefore, remains committed to the national forest policy statement and its central goals of creating a world‐class forest reserve system and providing long-term security for native forest based industries in the context of ecological and economic sustainability.

These are much the same words that Senator Hill used in his speech. I think those on the opposition side have to suddenly wake up. This is 1996. We have a coalition government in power. And you know what? Surprise, surprise—we talk to one another. As Senator Hill said, not only did the previous government not talk to one another; their staff did not talk to one another.

We have taken a whole of government approach to the process of government because we believe we were elected for all Australians and not just a narrow group. We recognise the Labor Party's sectional interest. They are the political arm of the trade union movement. They make no bones about it. And of course the minority parties tend to compete for the same narrow sectional group. Hence, we cannot have the Greens moving a motion in here or putting forward some sort of proposal without the Democrats coming in and saying, `Me, too.'

We believe the goals will be achieved through regional forest agreements between the Commonwealth and states. The commitment of this government to the sustainable management of the forest reserve is demonstrated by the provision of an extra $48 million for accelerating the RFA process. The comprehensive regional assessments leading to RFAs will be accelerated without compromising the integrity of the process to achieve a lasting solution to the forest policy impasse of the past decade.

Large areas of forests which might be needed to establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system are now protected under the deferred forest agreements and interim forest agreements with the states. Industry is restricted to harvesting in areas approved by the former Labor government under deferred and interim forest agreements. These agreements identify all areas that might be required by a CAR reserve system, and the states have agreed not to harvest in those areas either for export or for domestic use.

This agreement not to harvest those possible CAR reserve areas is of much more conservation value than a ban on the export of pulpwood after the trees have been harvested. RFAs will be negotiated to ensure that a CAR reserve system is established and that harvesting outside those areas is done in an ecologically sustainable manner.

I recently sat through the estimates hearings where Senator Brown questioned officials in relation to potential domestic use of wood that is currently exported. The government recognises medium‐ to long‐term supply security is a critical issue for the industry. The decisions of the former Labor government created a great deal of uncertainty for the forest based industries and the communities dependent on those industries. Many billions of dollars principally for value adding projects in fibre board, wood pulp and paper production would be invested by the forest industries if they were certain about long-term government policy direction and the security of resource supply, enabling more woodchips to be utilised domestically.

It must be recognised that the pulpwood that is being exported as woodchips is entirely unsuitable for producing products such as furniture or other sawn timber products. It is, however, entirely suitable for production of printing grade paper, and the export market therefore offers the highest return for this valuable resource. There is certainly no evidence that any domestic processor which requires pulpwood for its operations has ever been lacking in material. The regulations to which we will revert if this motion is successful, the old unprocessed wood regulations which predated Labor's ill-conceived arrangements, which were disallowed by the House of Representatives, are adequate to implement the government's transitional woodchip licensing policy.

We have heard a lot about forest policy from Labor Party shadow ministers since the election, but what we have heard particularly in relation to regulations is they have not learnt any lessons. They have failed to see that the states are absolutely committed to the national forest policy statement, that it is in their interests to get regional forest agreements in place and the Commonwealth out of their hair. Yet, instead of working with the states in a spirit of cooperative federalism, they have treated them with disdain and introduced the ill-conceived woodchip export regulations disallowed recently by the coalition.

Perhaps the most pernicious feature of these regulations was the two-stage licensing process under which the volume of woodchips allowed to be exported from any state was slashed if the states failed to achieve agreed milestones towards implementing regional forest agreements. The government recognises that we must set deadlines for the implementation of national forest agreements. But punitive approaches such as those adopted by Labor are simply counterproductive. We have set some boundaries for our negotiations with the states. The regulations currently before the Senate will ensure that from 1 January 2000 woodchip exports will not be permitted from areas not covered by regional forest agreements. The states understand this condition is immoveable.

Finally, I wish to make the point that the government is not trying to mislead the public into believing that all woodchip exports from our forests will cease in the year 2000. Woodchips will continue to be exported under regional forest agreements as part of an integrated, sustainable and internationally competitive native forest logging industry. The previous government's position was precisely the same. If it has changed, they should have the courage to come out and say so.

While the government recognises this decision on forest policy has not met the demands of all stakeholders, it is a firm and balanced decision consistent with its recognition of the regard that all Australians have for our forests for their outstanding natural qualities and source of sustainable employment and wealth.

The new regulations introduced by this government were not greeted by the outcry that accompanied the making of Labor's ill-conceived and illogical regulations in November last year. In fact they have been broadly welcomed by the community and, in particular, by communities in which people's livelihood depends directly upon an ecologically sustainable timber industry. I urge all senators to vote against this motion before us today.

I have seen all of these three different options in practice in different areas in Western Australia where there has been magnificent re‐establishment of forest.

A picture comes to mind where in the early days some areas of karri forest was cut out. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am pleased to have this opportunity to speak in favour of the disallowance of the Howard government's iniquitous new woodchip export regulations. Much was made in the previous address of ceilings. In my view, the ceiling referred to is a false one. Talking about a ceiling in the government regulations is cynical and manipulative. It is a ceiling so far above any reasonable assessment of what is sustainable from our forests that no practical benefit can be construed from it as a ceiling. It is simply public relations rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: These new government regulations pave the way for disaster, not only for publicly owned and privately owned native forests but also for the timber industry itself—in particular, for the emerging plantation‐based timber industry. The regulations move in a direction directly opposite to that which is required in order to sustain development in regional Australia and to sustain the fastest growing industry in the forest region of south‐west Western Australia—tourism.

The native forest woodchip industry is in a rush to sell off the native forest woodchips now because those woodchips are, as Judy Clark and others have said, of relatively poor quality and will soon be displaced by better quality plantation chips from around the world. In drafting and gazetting these regulations, the government has collaborated with the native forest woodchip industry to enable them to strip our old‐growth native forests in these last few years before the woodchips will not be able to be given away.

These new regulations are a significant step along the path of the deregulation of the woodchip industry in particular and the timber industry in general. This deregulation at a Commonwealth government level is part of its plan to remove itself entirely, or as much as possible, from any area of environmental control or regulation.

Under these woodchip regulations, and in association with the regional forest agreement process, the Commonwealth is trying to wash its hands of the forests and the issuing of woodchip export licences. It will then be down to the states to control, monitor and regulate, if they choose to—and their record so far is almost universally appalling.

These woodchip regulations will either give rise to or fail to prevent the following harmful and regressive outcomes. There will be substantial increases in the volume of export woodchips from native forests both publicly and privately owned. There will be increased or continued logging of old‐growth forest to produce mainly woodchips. There will be increased or continuing encouragement to the woodchip industry to consume large volumes of old‐growth forest logs which could and should be used to produce sawn timber for high quality timber products.

There will be increased or continuing pressure to allocate old‐growth native forest to timber production rather than other more benign and labour intensive uses, such as tourism. There will be increased incentive to export plantation wood as woodchips or whole logs rather than encouraging downstream processing. There will be ongoing entrenchment and subsidisation of the native forest timber industry at the expense of the far more sustainable plantation‐based timber industry. And there will be ministerial intervention on behalf of the environment becoming almost entirely discretionary.

Already, in expectation of these new regulations, in my own state of Western Australia the woodchip exporters of Wesfarmers Bunnings and Whittakers have applied for an effective 41 per cent increase in their total woodchip export quotas. It should be noted that at least one of these companies is a major contributor to the coalition political parties to the tune of thousands of dollars annually while being a beneficiary of these new regulations.

These same companies have been and continue to be in breach of legally binding state and Commonwealth conditions. In 1994 an official Commonwealth investigation found that Wesfarmers Bunnings was likely to have breached its woodchip export conditions in relation to the logging of the magnificent old‐growth karri forests in the Giblett block near Pemberton.

Another official investigation is currently under way in relation to claims from a Western Australian sawmill operator that third‐grade sawlogs are being sent to the woodchip mill to be used for woodchips. This is a further breach of legally binding conditions under the state agreement which, in turn, are incorporated into the woodchip licence conditions.

The WA Department of Environmental Protection has recently reported that Whittakers, through its subsidiary Southern Plantations Chip Company, has not complied with state conditions on its export woodchip operations. We have an ongoing record of failure to comply with the letter, let alone the spirit, of woodchip export licences and agreements.

PARA.BREAK: Like the majority—and I stress `majority'—of people from my home state of Western Australia, I am opposed to the ongoing massive level of clear‐felling operations taking place in WA's unique old‐growth karri and jarrah forests. Each year, according to WA government figures, WA is losing be tween 10,000 and 15,000 hectares of old‐growth forests to clear‐felling and other forms of intensive logging operations. The Resource Assessment Commission inquiry into the timber industry stated in its 1992 final report:

SPEECH.PARA: The logging of old growth forests potentially violates the precautionary principle in that an irreplaceable resource is being destroyed.

Contrary to woodchip industry misinformation, old‐growth forests are not a renewable resource. They are being wiped out and they will not return. Despite the self-serving manipulation—and I stress `manipulation'—of definitions that the industry and government persist with, it is well understood that there are qualities and attributes unique to old‐growth forests that arise from their pristineness and their continuity over the ages.

These qualities and attributes cannot and do not survive the massive assault that the modern industrial forestry business brings to bear with its combination of roading, clear‐felling, burning, poisoning, application of chemicals, alteration of species and genetic compositions, permanent impacts on aquatic ecosystems and the introduction or spread of weeds, diseases and feral animals.

Contrary to woodchip industry misinformation, the woodchip industry is not and never has been a residue industry. Most of the wood that is produced from the clear‐felling operations in WA's old‐growth karri and jarrah forests goes to woodchips. Only a relatively small proportion actually ends up as sawn timber. For example, for the year 1993—which was a typical year—WA produced 231,000 cubic metres of sawn timber from native forests and 815,000 cubic metres of woodchips from native forests. How could 815,000 be a residue of 231,000? I say again that it is not and never has been the case that the woodchip industry is a residue industry coming along and politely cleaning up the leftovers from sawlog operations.

PARA.BREAK: The WA woodchip industry uses mainly whole logs, not branches and sawmill offcuts as industry and government misinformation seeks to suggest. In 1994, for example, 90 per cent of the input was in the form of whole logs and just 10 per cent was sawmill resi dues. In that same year—and the situation is probably worse now, given the slump in demand for sawn timber—45 per cent of all logs taken from WA's native forests went straight to the chipper. It is rape, and rape in a big way.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason the woodchipping industry is so desperate to hang on to its privileged access to Australia's old‐growth native forests is simple: it is a very profitable industry. The reason it is very profitable is that it consumes very large volumes of good quality whole logs which it gets very cheaply from our forests, courtesy of the governments to which they make political donations. It expends almost nothing in terms of labour and processing costs, and then sells the chips to Japan at a very handsome profit per unit volume and sells to other foreign countries.

Even though the per unit volume value of woodchips may well be less than the per unit volume value of sawn timber, when the huge volumes produced and the very large profit margins per unit volume are taken into consideration it is easy to see why massive quantities of logs that could be used to produce sawn timber are used, instead, to produce woodchips.

We have had various reports in the West Australian about woodchipping of those logs in July this year. It is the woodchip industry, not sawn timber production, which drives the logging of WA's old‐growth native forests. The big woodchip companies, such as Wesfarmers‐Bunnings in WA, never reveal how much profit they make from woodchips as opposed to sawn timber. They only ever talk in terms of the per unit volume value of woodchips versus sawn timber. There is a conspiracy of silence between the government and those companies as to the real facts of the matter.

PARA.BREAK: As I have explained, this gives a deliberately false impression of the real overall profitablilty of woodchipping versus sawn timber production. It is because woodchipping drives the native forest industry that we see little or no decrease in the level of logging in our native forests at a time when there is a long‐term slump in sawn timber demand. In WA the state government has a legally bind ing commitment to supply Wesfarmers‐Bunnings with 680,000 tonnes of logs suitable for woodchipping every year. This means that even if sawlogs or sawn timber are not required or cannot be sold, the supply of chip logs must be and is maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: The entrenchment of the woodchip industry in old‐growth native forests, which these new regulations will facilitate, leaves the way open for ongoing direct conflict with the needs of the tourism industry in WA. Tourism industry reports and industry operators point out that too little has been done and is being done to provide a secure base for the tourism industry of the south‐west of WA. The industry recognises and acknowledges that the old‐growth forests of the region are a crucial feature that it depends on for its future growth, sustainability and attractiveness as an environment. That is why people come to Australia—for the environment. They do not come to Australia to look at sawmill logs in woodchip factories.

Many of the south‐west's most spectacular and high conservation value old‐growth forests are, under existing state government plans, destined for clear‐felling and woodchipping. Forests like Sharpe, Jane and Giblett, and many more, are scheduled for destruction. With less than 20 per cent of WA's native forests in secure dedicated conservation reserves, the industry—I refer to the tourism industry and the plantation timber industry—have good reason to be concerned. Although the regional forest agreement process is supposed to investigate these issues, as far as WA is concerned that process has itself been taken over by a state government which has repeatedly stated that almost no more forest is required for conservation.

The Howard government makes some claims about regional development and employment. Minister Sharp is on record as identifying the government's commitment to woodchipping as a key element in its approach to regional development. I refer to a media statement from John Sharp, dated 20 August 1996. He said:

. . . a new woodchip export licensing system which will allow for an additional 1 million tonnes of woodchip to be sourced from sawmill residues, all provide evidence of this Government's commitment to rural Australia.

The shareholders of Wesfarmers and Bunnings do not live in rural Australia. I can tell the government that the WA woodchip industry, despite the massive quantities of forests and logs it consumes, is a very low employer. The entire industry directly employs only about 200 people. The tourism industry in the Pemberton region alone is fast reaching this number of employees. That—and I refer to the tourism industry—is the industry of the future for the south‐west. That is the industry that can provide for long‐term jobs and regional economic well‐being.

Encouragement of a sustainable nature based tourism industry in combination with encouragement of a large plantation and farm forest based timber and pulp industry is the best way to ensure the environmental economic and social future of the south‐west of WA, not the creation of a wasteland of trees. If the Howard government is really interested in regional development, then protecting old growth forests rather than consigning them to woodchipping oblivion is a far more fruitful policy.

I am strongly opposed to these new regulations which will serve only one purpose; the favouring of the entrenchment of native forest woodchipping at the expense of every other community concern and potential benefit, including those of our new industries such as tourism. The government appears to have completely misunderstood the costs of woodchipping and the opportunities provided by other forms of other industry development. It needs to go away and have a good long think about its priorities, not about its mates, and then come back to this place with a set of regulations that will discourage woodchipping of native forests and, instead, encourage timber industry development outside old growth forests. The government needs to demonstrate that it has developed a far more sophisticated understanding of this issue, not merely an understanding of its political debts, rather than simply offering these completely inadequate and inappropriate regulations as a gesture of political support to its mates in their beleaguered and greedy woodchip industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today mention was made of one of Australia's great conservation figures, Alec Marr, in a disparaging fashion. I rise to acquaint the Senate with the role that this sterling citizen has played in the evolution of conservation thinking in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As we sit here, he is on his way to—or is already at—the World Conservation Union Conference in Montreal, which is the get together once every three years of the umbrella group of the world's conservation organisations and government officers, the premier world conference on conservation. If the conference is anything like his contribution to the last of these conferences in Buenos Aires in 1993—I was there with Alec—he will take one of the lead roles in the outcomes of that conference. Some governments and vested interests may not like it, but when a person is committed—in this case, it is Alec—not to the monetary values that seem to be the measure of excellence with so many people in this place but instead to giving his life to trying to rescue this planet from the rapid and serial degradation of its environment he deserves better.

Alec Marr came to the Wilderness Society in Hobart a good many years ago—in the mid‐1980s. He did not have a tertiary education ticket behind him; he had a much wider and more important ticket, however, and that was in worldly wisdom. From his background as a bricklayer—maybe that was where he got his contemplation—he was able to see that things needed fixing. Coming from Newcastle, for a while he brought his sister and his brother and they found themselves in the heat of the Farmhouse Creek dispute south of Hobart, where World Heritage value forests were being invaded by the woodchip companies that are so much still under discussion.

PARA.BREAK: It is a long story, but Alec got out his ropes and went 40 metres up into the lower branches of one of the giant trees which scrape the sky at a height of 80, 90 or 100 metres in the Picton River valley. He sat there on a platform for weeks. It was right in the way of the road. Finally, the woodchip companies brought in two bus loads of loggers as vigi lantes to beat up the conservationists. One of those, Anthony Risby, one of the supremos of one of the logging companies in Tasmania, was later convicted of assault under civil suit. Many others should have been convicted but were not.

SPEECH.PARA: Alec stayed on his platform in the tree even as these vigilantes drove their chainsaws into the butt of that giant tree. I remember looking out from under a bulldozer in the base of Farmhouse Creek as the same villains swung their chainsaws around among a group of young women hanging onto some small rainforest trees and cut the trees from between their shins. I remember the report of another conservationist who was near throttled by these thugs from the logging companies who were bussed in on that day. I remember watching the police in the invidious position where I believe they had instructions from the then liberal government not to intervene—in fact, I was told that by one of them—as they stood helplessly aside with their arms folded. It was, to say the least, an inglorious episode. But throughout it all Alec Marr stayed on his perch.

Later, when the Liberal government of Robin Gray in Tasmania had brought in rules to exclude the media from covering this dispute, they were then able to send in the necessary equipment to finally get Alec out of that tree. But in the meantime he had held up for weeks and weeks the progress of that destructive road into the Farmhouse Creek wilderness and tall eucalypt forests containing some of the tallest flowering plants on the face of the planet.

To keep this story short, not long after that that area, due to the national outcry, was protected by being listed as a World Heritage area. The tree in which Alec sat for so long was cut down before that event, but I think he as much as anybody else, if not more than, can take credit for one of the most wonderful forest environments in the world. To its north the devastating clear‐fell destruction of similar forests is going ahead right now under the hand of this government. Alec can stand proud and, unlike many members opposite and his critics, look future generations fair and square in the eye and say, `At least I tried.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise to speak of Edmund Rice, the founder of the Christian Brothers, who was beatified in Rome on 6 October this year. Just recently we have witnessed the beatification of Mary MacKillop, an Australian nun, and the similarities between them are quite remarkable. The process of beatification is a rigorous one and is widely seen as a step towards sainthood.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let me say something of the history of the man Edmund Rice. Edmund Ignatius Rice was born in Callan, a small town in County Kilkenny, Ireland, in 1762 and he died at Waterford in 1844. During his life he acquired a well documented reputation as a person who did good works and was a successful businessman. One might think that is a rather hard task to achieve, bearing in mind that on the one hand you have charity and on the other hand you have commerce.

He was apprenticed to his uncle Michael, who was a wealthy merchant in the thriving southern city port of Waterford. He was aged 17 and was fully conversant with livestock and the provision trade. He eventually inherited that business, but did not give up or desist from his work for the poor. If he stood out amongst his contemporaries, it was because of the deeply personal aspect of his solicitude. He did more than give money to the needy; he gave them his time, his hospitality and, finally, his very life.

After a full day's work, he put in long hours aiding orphans, elderly and homeless people. He was an active member of several organisations which raised funds for charitable institutions. He often served as an advocate to obtain rights and benefits for persons too poor to hire a lawyer. In fact, he assisted anyone in need. Of special concern to him were the wild and uncared for boys who gathered around the timber stacks on the quay. He brought them to his home in Barrack Street and provided them with food and clothing.

Edmund Rice was also a scholar and one of the subscribers to the 1791 edition of the Douay Bible, which he read very carefully. He opposed vehemently usury and the exploitation of the poor and any other of the injustices which were then rampant in society.

In spite of government pressure on Catholics in 18th century Ireland, Edmund Rice made no secret of his faith. He attended mass daily in Waterford churches and joined other men in prayer or action groups to promote his religion. He was an adviser and friend to many priests and a bishop.

He married Mary Elliot when he was aged 25. Two years later his young wife died giving birth to their daughter, who never developed normally. His wife's death was a watershed in his life and for the next 13 years he sought out a reason and meaning for the suffering that she had endured.

He finally made up his mind to sell his successful business and to devote the rest of his life to teaching the poor gratuitously. In 1802 as a layman he founded a community of teaching brothers that would eventually become two separate congregations in the church—the Presentation Brothers and the Christian Brothers. Nearly 200 years later, the Christian Brothers order is active in some 30 countries around the world.

Edmund Rice's first attempt to establish a school was a venture in a rented building which was a stable on New Street in Waterford, where he conducted a free school for the poorest boys in the city. He hired teachers to assist him, but after a few weeks they quit because the work was so difficult. Of course, these boys had never been to a school like that before. In fact, none of them had been near any form of education.

He continued alone with some 150 boys to instruct. At the end of the year, two young men from Callan volunteered their services and they moved into a loft above the stable to live with Edmund Rice. This was the inauspicious beginning of the Christian Brothers. In 1809 they were allowed to take religious vows. By this time there were five brothers and they had moved to their newly constructed school called Mount Sion. There were many schools in Waterford at this time, but none for boys that were unable to pay for their education.

Political conditions in Ireland at this time militated against schools such as Mount Sion. Thus, in giving up his prosperous business and his comfortable home, Edmund Rice was embarking on a career that would result in giving hope and new life to children who were faced with the prospect of no education nor any advancement.

BREAK.PARA: Throughout the world Christian Brothers have been responsible for the education of millions of children. In Australia today Christian Brothers have educated approximately 500,000 children in over 80 schools since their arrival in Melbourne in 1867. Christian Brothers, I believe, continue the commitment that Edmund Rice showed nearly 200 years ago in their education commitment to young children not only in this country but worldwide. It is worth while that the Senate note the beatification of this great man which occurred, as I say, this month in Rome.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tarkine Wilderness: Erection of Telecommunications Aerial

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is responsible for the erection of a telecommunications aerial 3 kilometres north‐east of Mt Donaldson in north‐west Tasmania (map reference 939405, Pieman 1:100 000 sheet 7914).
(2) What is the purpose of this installation and why was it erected in this particular area.
(3) Is the Minister aware that this site is part of an area registered on the Interim List of the National Estate, and known as the Tarkine Wilderness.
(4) Was the Australian Heritage Commission advised of the proposal to establish a facility in this area; if so, what was its response.
(5) Was an environmental impact assessment done; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Telstra advises that it is responsible for the installation of a repeater near Mt Donaldson in north‐west Tasmania. However, it advises that the map reference for the site the honourable senator has referred to is incorrect. Telstra's repeater is located at map reference Zone 55, Easting 340900, Northing 539400 near the Pieman River State Reserve.

(2) Telstra further advises that the repeater was installed to upgrade a service to customers in Corinna, whose service had been experiencing difficulties with marginal performance. The provision of a repeater at the site was considered the only reasonable way of providing the service required.

(3) I have been advised by the Department of Communications and the Arts that the site is located within the Tarkine Wilderness which, I have also been advised, was entered in the interim list for the Register of the National Estate on 30 May 1995.
(4) No. Before installing the Facility, I am advised Telstra notified the relevant State authority, in this case the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Land Management.

The Department of Environment and Land Management advised Telstra that the proposed site for the repeater was under the control of Forestry Tasmania. Telstra subsequently held negotiations with Forestry Tasmania leading to the establishment of a lease for the site on 30 May 1996.

Telstra advises that it did not notify the Australian Heritage Commission at the time of its proposal to install the repeater as it had formed the view, on the basis of advice from the Department of Environment and Land Management, that the facility was not likely to have a significant effect on a place, or its immediate surroundings, that is entered in either the Register of the National Estate or the interim list for the Register of the National Estate.

The Department of Communications and the Arts has subsequently notified all relevant parties of this development and requested AUSTEL, which has responsibility for monitoring compliance with the Telecommunications National Code, to investigate this matter in consultation with the Australian Heritage Commission and Telstra.

Recent advice from Telstra indicates that it is seeking to address this outstanding requirement under the Telecommunications National Code (that is, to provide the Australian Heritage Commission with enough information to assess the impact of the installation) as a matter of priority. I understand that the Australian Heritage Commission has agreed to undertake an urgent assessment of the impact of the installation.
(5) In accordance with the Telecommunications National Code, Telstra advises that a Prescribed Activity Notice was prepared for the proposed installation and forwarded to:
(a) the Department of Environment and Land Management, Division of Environmental Management and the Office of the Surveyor General;
(b) the Managing Director, Forestry Tasmania; and
(c) the District Forester, North‐West Region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 18 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Equestrian Federation of Australia still funded by the Commonwealth Government; if not, when did this funding cease.
(2) If the funding is still in existence, what is the amount of funding provided and what are the terms and conditions of the funding agreement.
(3) Does the Equestrian Federation of Australia deal with matters such as the use of whips during sporting contests or race meetings.
(4) Is the Government aware of any changes to the guidelines governing the use of the whip since the release of a report in 1991 by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare.
(5) Is it the case that rules governing the use of the whip in the United Kingdom are more stringent than the equivalent Australian rules.
(6) What body or bodies regulate the use of the whip and does the Federal Government play a role in co-ordinating such regulation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Equestrian Federation of Australia (EFA) is a recognised national sporting organisation currently receiving funding under the Federal Government's sports assistance programs, which are administered by the Australian Sports Commission.

(2) In 1995/96 the EFA received grants from the Sports Assistance Scheme ($431,720) and the Olympic Athlete Program ($729,600) totalling $1,161,320. A copy of the terms and conditions pertaining to grant expenditure and acquittal has been provided to the honourable senator, as printed below.

(3) The EFA is not responsible for rules governing use of the whip at race meetings. It only deals with matters regarding the use of whips during sporting contests conducted by its three disciplines (eventing, show jumping and dressage) where the general ethos is that the welfare of the horse is paramount.

(4) Since the release of a report in 1991 by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, the Australian Conference of Principal Clubs (ACPC) has added specific requirements to the Australian Rules of Racing.
In October 1994 the Australian Rules of Racing (137A) were extended to include the following :
(i) Stewards may punish any rider who, in a race, or trial, or trackwork, uses his whip in an excessive, unnecessary or improper manner;
(ii) Stewards may punish any rider who in a race or trial uses his whip—
(a) forward of the horse's shoulder or in the vicinity of his head;
(b) when the horse is out of contention; or
(c) when the horse is showing no response; or
(d) when the horse is clearly winning; or
(e) when the horse has passed the winning post.

(5) Rules governing the use of the whip in the United Kingdom are slightly more stringent than those governing the use of the whip in Australia. In the UK a jockey is restricted in the number of times he or she can use the whip on a horse when it is in the straight. In Australia there is no limit to the number of a times a jockey can use the whip on a horse when it is in the straight.

(6) The use of the whip at race meetings is governed by the Australian Conference of Principal Clubs which includes the AJC, VRC and all principal racing clubs throughout Australia. This Conference sets the Australian Rules of Racing which govern the use of whips at race meetings throughout Australia. In relation to grants made pursuant to the SAS, a funded NSO or NSOD will be required to agree to:
with respect to management functions:

PARA.TAB: have in place a satisfactory Development Plan covering a three to four year period, incorporating performance indicators against which the effectiveness of ASC funding will be objectively measured;
complete and submit an annual review of progress towards achieving the objectives specified in the Development Plan;
provide the ASC with annual updates to the Development Plan including amendments arising from the annual review and the addition of another year to the planning horizon;
have a process to accurately record the number of member participants in the sport by type and gender;
invite the ASC to he represented at meetings of the sport;
provide copies of duty statements and selection criteria for all NSO administration and coaching positions;
invite the ASC to be involved in the selection of any officials supported by funds from the ASC; and
respond promptly to ASC requests for information and advice.

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to financial obligations:

PARA.TAB: enter a Cooperative Arrangement with the ASC for the period of the grant;

provide Statements of Final Costs or other requested financial documentation authorised by a qualified auditor who does not hold a position in the NSO or NSOD certifying that the grant moneys received were spent in accordance with the terms and conditions of the grant and that the grant was expended within the specified period of the grant;
obtain the agreement of the ASC prior to using any part of the grant moneys for purposes other than that specified in the advice letter and Cooperative Arrangement; and
provide formal advice to the ASC of any unexpended funds, and seek formal approval to carry forward unexpended funds in accordance with the ASC's carry forward guidelines.

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to international competition:

PARA.TAB: promulgate selection procedures for athletes for Australian national teams well in advance of team selection, and submit a copy of these to the ASC;
submit a proposed international competition program for the forthcoming financial year to the ASC no later than 31 March each year, unless otherwise notified;
not participate in international competition involving any country against which sanctions endorsed by the Australian Government are in force; and
provide appropriate performance and other requested reports of Australian teams and individuals in international competition (see "with respect to reporting" below).

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to training camps:

PARA.TAB: submit to the ASC an annual plan outlining the proposed program for camps for the forthcoming financial year no later than 31 March each year, unless otherwise notified;
conduct camps in accordance with approved National Sports Program guidelines; and
provide appropriate reports on National Sports Program funded training camps (see "with respect to reporting" below).

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to the development of sport for special population (equity target) groups e.g. women, Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, athletes with a disability:

PARA.TAB: include satisfactory objectives and performance indicators for some or all of these groups in the NSO's or NSOD's Development Plan;

ANSWER.PARA: for identified NSODs and NSOs to display a commitment to the major objectives of the ASC Aussie Able Program for sport for people with a disability, ie to:

PARA.TAB: increase and strengthen grass roots access and participation;
strengthen sports and coaching development for elite athletes with a disability;
support the development of a strong body to co-ordinate Paralympic preparation;
continue to work towards integration and the inclusion of disabled athletes into mainstream sport (where appropriate); and
increase and strengthen the co-ordination mechanism of disabled sport.

ANSWER.PARA: apply principles of equal opportunity in all operations and develop action plans, incorporating special measures to advance access and equity for women and other disadvantaged groups;
in particular, develop and implement a gender equity action plan to improve women's access to opportunities and status in the NSO or NSOD.
with respect to doping policy:

PARA.TAB: abide by the provisions of the ASC's Doping Policy or a doping policy approved by the ASC;
obtain approval from the ASC to vary its doping policy;
provide the ASC with a copy of the current doping policy of the relevant international sporting federation and notify the ASC immediately of any amendments to that international policy;

notify the ASC's Executive Director of the name of any athlete who has recorded a positive result or who has failed to provide a sample for testing and the action the NSO or NSOD has taken or intends to take;
observe sanctions imposed by any other NSO or NSOD under the terms of the ASC's Doping Policy.

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to reporting:

PARA.TAB: provide the ASC with a copy of the NSOs or NSODs annual report and audited annual financial statements within one month of completion;
regularly submit full financial and performance reports of each international competition attended to include:
the name, venue and dates of the event;
the names of the Australian team members (athletes, officials, coaches, support staff and sports science and medical practitioners);
a list of participating nations and the total number of competitors;
full results or the results of all Australian competitors;
the total expenditure of the competition broken down into six categories:
international airfares;
domestic airfares (when not part of international airfares);
accommodation and meals;
ground transportation;
freight and excess baggage charges for equipment and horses; and
other expenses.

ANSWER.PARA: regularly submit full financial and performance reports of each National Sports Program funded training campus not held at the Australian Institute of Sport campus in Canberra to include:

PARA.TAB: the name, venue and dates of the camp;
the outline of the camp program;
the names of the camp participants (athletes, officials, coaches, support staff and sports science and medical practitioners);
the total expenditure of the competition or camp broken down into eight categories:
international airfares;
domestic airfares;
facility hire;
accommodation and meals;
ground transportation;
fees for professional services;
freight and excess baggage charges for equipment and horses; and
other expenses.

ANSWER.PARA: with respect to ASC recognition:

PARA.TAB: treat the ASC as a major corporate sponsor and provide exposure for the ASC at every appropriate opportunity;
acknowledge the ASC in press releases and media interviews whenever possible;

use the ASC logo or the words "supported by the Australian Sports Commission" on videos and manuals, promotional material (posters, print and electronic media advertisements etc) and official programs and newsletters for major events, as appropriate;
use the ASC logo and/or inclusion of the words `. . . is supported by the Australian Sports Commission" in advertisements for positions;
acknowledge the ASC in annual reports and other reports and programs;

when hosting a major international event in Australia with the support of the ASC, contact the ASC to discuss other acknowledgment of the ASC (eg naming rights when no major sponsor is secured, corporate box, VIP tickets, ASC corporate advertisements in the official program, other);
